facts.text: In 1954, the Assam Government took possession of the lands of the respondent and several other persons situated in the District of Kamrup for the construction of the Pagdalia embankment.

In 1955, the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Ordinance, 1955 (Assam Ordinance No. 2 of 1955) was passed enabling the State Government to acquire lands for works or other development measures in connection with flood control or prevention of erosion.

The Ordinance was replaced by the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Act, 1955 (Assam Act No. 6 of 1955) which was passed on April 11, 1955 with the assent of the President.

In April 1956, the State Government passed an order in writing acquiring the lands taken over in 1954 for the construction of the Pagdalia embankment under s. 3 of Ordinance No. 2 of 1955 (mistake, intended under Act No. 6 of 1955).
On April 26, 1956, the respondent was served with the notice of the acquisition.

By an order dated September 10, 1959, the Deputy Commissioner, Kamrup acting on behalf of the State Government quashed the Order dated April 19, 1956 and directed that fresh acquisition proceedings under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 should be started.
Pursuant to this order, some of the lands required for the Pagdalia embankment were acquired under the Land Acquisition Act on payment of full compensation.

A draft notification for the acquisition of the respondent's lands under the Land Acquisition Act was sent by the Collector of Kamrup to the Assam Government for approval, but this proposal was eventually dropped.
On May 27, 1960, the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion (Validation) Act, 1959 (Assam Act No. 21 of 1960) was passed with the assent of the President.

In November 1960, the State Government passed an order for the acquisition of the respondent's lands under s. 3 of the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Act (common case before High Court that this was under s. 3 of Act No. 21 of 1960).
On November 6, 1960, the Collector of Kamrup served a notice upon the respondent informing him of the acquisition order and asking him to submit his claim for compensation.

On September 30, 1961, the respondent filed a writ petition in the Assam High Court asking for an order declaring Act No. 6 of 1955 and Act No. 21 of 1960 to be invalid and directing the State Government to forbear from giving effect to the notices issued thereunder.
The High Court allowed the petition and issued a writ of mandamus directing the State Government not to give effect to the notices issued under Act No. 21 of 1960.
The present appeal has been filed under a certificate granted by the High Court.

legal_issues.text: Is Act No. 6 of 1955 protected by Art. 31A?
Is Act No. 6 of 1955 protected by Art. 31(5)(b)(ii)?
Does Act No. 6 of 1955 infringe Art. 31(2)?
Is Act No. 6 of 1955 violative of Art. 14?
Is Act No. 21 of 1960 a law providing for acquisition of lands independently of Act No. 6 of 1955, and if not, is it valid?
If Act No. 21 of 1960 is independent: a) protected by Art. 31A? b) by Art. 31(5)(b)(ii)? c) contravenes Art. 31(2)? d) violative of Art. 14?

petitioner_arguments.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 is a law providing for the acquisition of estates and is protected by Art. 31A(1)(a).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 31A; Kochuni case; Ranjit Singh v. State of Punjab; P.V. Mudaliar v. Special Deputy Collector

petitioner_arguments.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 is a law for the prevention of danger to life or property within Art. 31(5)(b)(ii).
The two Acts are not violative of Arts. 14 and 31(2) and are protected by Arts. 31A and 31(5)(b)(ii).
Act No. 21 of 1960 is a piece of legislation providing for acquisition of land independently of Act No. 6 of 1955.
In view of Art. 254(2), Act No. 6 of 1955 supersedes LA Act 1894 for flood control purposes.

respondent_arguments.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 and Act No. 21 of 1960 contravene Arts. 14 and 31(2). Compensation under Act 6 is illusory and inadequate.
Act No. 6 of 1955 violative of Art. 14 as State can choose between it and LA Act at will.

court_reasoning.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 is not a law concerning agrarian reform and is not protected by Art. 31A. It is a purely expropriatory measure for flood control, not related to land tenures or intermediaries.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 31A envisages only laws concerning agrarian reform.

court_reasoning.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 is not protected by Art. 31(5)(b)(ii) as it is a law for acquisition of property, not mere prevention of danger to life or property like destruction in emergencies. Police power does not extend to permanent acquisition without compensation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cl. 5(b)(ii) saves laws for promotion of public health or prevention of danger, but not for permanent acquisition.

court_reasoning.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 contravenes Art. 31(2) as it stood before Fourth Amendment because compensation (multiple of land revenue) does not ensure just equivalent of market value.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Compensation limited to 40/15 times annual land revenue is illusory; no relation to market value.

court_reasoning.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 violates Art. 14 by discriminating between lands acquired under it (nominal compensation) and under LA Act 1894 (market value) for similar public purposes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reasonable classification; adjacent lands treated differently.

court_reasoning.text: Act No. 21 of 1960 deems acquisitions under invalid Act No. 6 valid; cannot validate unconstitutional acquisitions. Dependent on Act 6, so invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deeming provision in s.2 invalid as earlier Act unconstitutional; ancillary provisions fall.

holdings.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 is not protected by Art. 31A or 31(5)(b)(ii), violates Art. 31(2) and Art. 14.
Act No. 6 of 1955 violates Art. 31(2) as compensation not just equivalent.
Act No. 6 of 1955 violates Art. 14 due to discriminatory compensation compared to LA Act.
Act No. 21 of 1960 invalid as it deems acquisitions under invalid Act No. 6 to be valid.

precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 31A saves laws for agrarian reform only.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ranjit Singh v. State of Punjab
P. V. Mudaliar v. Special Deputy Collector, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Housing acquisition not agrarian reform; violates Art. 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of Art. 31(1) and (2); taking of property.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 31(1),(2),(5)(b)(ii); eminent domain vs police power.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Bela Banerjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Compensation must be just equivalent under Art. 31(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd. v. State of Madras
State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar
P. V. Mudaliar v. Dy. Collector

statutes_cited.name: Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned Act for speedy acquisition; provides inadequate compensation; held invalid under Arts. 14, 31(2).

statutes_cited.name: Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion (Validation) Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Validates prior acquisitions under Act 6; held invalid as dependent on unconstitutional Act 6.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: General acquisition law providing market value compensation; contrast shows discrimination.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Embankment and Drainage Act, 1941
statutes_cited.relevance: Allows flood control without acquisition; compensation for losses.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 14 equality; Art. 31 property rights; Act 6 violates 14,31(2); not saved by 31A or 31(5)(b)(ii).

outcome.summary: The appeal against the High Court's declaration of invalidity of Act No. 6 of 1955 and Act No. 21 of 1960 and writ of mandamus is dismissed. Both Acts held unconstitutional under Arts. 14 and 31(2). Notices under Act 21 invalid.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order upheld; State directed not to give effect to notices.

key_quotes.text: "Act No. 6 of 1955 does not ensure payment of a just equivalent of the land appropriated and is violative of Art. 31(2) as it stood before the Fourth Amendment."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The classification of land required for works... in connection with flood control... and land required for other public purposes has no reasonable relation to the object... There is unjust discrimination."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Clause 5(b)(ii) was not intended to except laws for the acquisition of property, from the purview of cl. (2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
